question: Question_A_28
statement:
Let

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\textrm{Rot}_\alpha$ be the matrix for 2D rotation counterclockwise
  with angle $\alpha$
\item
  $\textrm{Refl}_\beta$ be the matrix for 2D reflection through the line
  that makes angle $\beta$ with the positive $x$ axis
\item
  $\textrm{Proj}_\theta$ be the matrix for 2D projection onto the line
  that makes angle $\theta$ with the positive $x$ axis.
\end{itemize}

Circle \emph{all} the matrix products below that are the identity matrix
for all $\alpha$,$\beta$,$\theta$.

(a)$\textrm{Refl}_\beta\textrm{Refl}_\beta$

(b)$\textrm{Rot}_\alpha\textrm{Rot}_{-\alpha}$

(c)$\textrm{Proj}_\theta\textrm{Proj}_\theta$

(d)$\textrm{Proj}_\theta\textrm{Proj}_{\pi/2-\theta}$

(e)$\textrm{Rot}_\alpha\textrm{Refl}_{\alpha/2}$
sols:
By the position of this question inside the exam, and given that it is a
multiple choice question, it is very likely that a conceptual answer is
sufficient.

\textbf{Conceptual Answer:}

With a good understanding of vector geometry, we can quickly see which
operations are equivalent to the identity matrix. Recall that the
identity matrix means that the vector you finish with is the same as the
vector you begin with. We will go through each scenario and argue
whether the net transformation recovers the original vector.

(a)$\textrm{Refl}_\beta\textrm{Refl}_\beta$:

Recall that a reflection is angle preserving. For example, if we have a
vector \textbf{u} that we want to reflect over some vector \textbf{v}
and there is a counter-clockwise angle $\theta$ from \textbf{u} to
\textbf{v} then the reflection will produce a new vector \textbf{x} that
is a counter-clockwise angle $\theta$ from \textbf{v}, i.e. $2\theta$
counter-clockwise from \textbf{u}. Therefore, in this case we have a
vector that we are instructed to reflect over a line at an angle $\beta$
from the $x$-axis. We are then instructed to take the new vector and
reflect it once again over the same line. In other words we are asking
for a ``mirror-image of a mirror-image'' which is the original vector.
Therefore, we \textbf{do} get that this operation is equivalent to an
identity matrix.

(b)$\textrm{Rot}_\alpha\textrm{Rot}_{-\alpha}$:

In this example we take a vector and for the first operation, rotate it
an angle $\alpha$. We then take the new vector and rotate it an angle
$-\alpha$. This is equivalent to spinning something clockwise and then
counter-clockwise by the same amount. Doing so would result in the
original vector and therefore we \textbf{do} get that this operation is
equivalent to an identity matrix.

(c)$\textrm{Proj}_\theta\textrm{Proj}_\theta$:

For this question we need to understand what a projection operation
does. If we want to project a vector \textbf{u} onto a vector \textbf{v}
then the net result will be to determine all the components of
\textbf{u} so that it lies parallel to \textbf{v} or points in the same
direction. Therefore, in this case if our vector \textbf{v} makes an
angle $\theta$ with the x-axis and we want to project some vector
\textbf{u} onto it then after the first projection operation we will
have a vector, \textbf{w} that lies on top of \textbf{v}. Any future
attempts to project this new vector onto \textbf{v} will result in an
identity because there is nothing left to make parallel to \textbf{v}.
Therefore applying a second projection operator will just map \textbf{w}
to itself. Therefore we have that we started with a vector \textbf{u}
and ended with a vector \textbf{w} which for arbitrary \textbf{u} is
\textbf{not} equivalent to an identity matrix operation. In fact the
only way it could be an identity matrix is if the original vector were
\textbf{v} itself so that the projection does nothing to the vector.

(d)$\textrm{Proj}_\theta\textrm{Proj}_{\pi/2-\theta}$:

Recall from part (c) that projection is an operation that traps vectors
to the original vector being projected on. This means that after one
operation, further projections onto the same vector will result in no
changes. Therefore in this example after the first operation we have a
resultant vector in the direction of a vector at an angle $\pi/2-\theta$
with the x-axis. After the second projection, our resultant vector is in
the direction of a vector making an angle $\theta$ with the x-axis.
Therefore, unless the original vector made an angle $\theta$ with the
x-axis then this resultant vector will not be the same as the original.
Therefore, for any arbitrary starting vector, this will \textbf{not} be
an identity matrix operation.

(e)$\textrm{Rot}_\alpha\textrm{Refl}_{\alpha/2}$:

In this example we consider taking an initial vector, reflecting it by
an angle of $\alpha/2$ and then rotating it counter-clockwise by an
angle $\alpha$. Consider if the original angle is clockwise of the
reflector at $\alpha/2$. In this case if we reflect it so that it is now
counter-clockwise to the reflector and rotate it even further
counter-clockwise then there is no way of returning to the original
vector. In order for it to be an identity operator, the operation has
has to return the original vector for any arbitrary initial vector. We
have shown with this class of examples that the operation will not
produce the original vector ever and so it can't hold for any arbitrary
initial vector. Therefore this is \textbf{not} an identity matrix
operation.

Therefore, we conclude that only \textbf{(a)} and \textbf{(b)} are
equivalent to identity matrix operations.

\textbf{Computational Solution:}

This question can of course also be solved computationally in terms of
transformation matrices if one were so inclined. We will present this
solution now as an exercise to those wishing to improve their
understanding of linear transformations and also to appease the worries
of those who struggle with understanding the conceptual framework in the
previous solutions.

For the purposes of short form we will denote the following matrices

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $A_\alpha$-the matrix corresponding to the transformation
  $\textrm{Rot}_\alpha$.
\item
  $B_\beta$-the matrix corresponding to the transformation
  $\textrm{Refl}_\beta$.
\item
  $C_\theta$-the matrix corresponding to the transformation
  $\textrm{Proj}_\theta$.
\end{itemize}

Recall that to obtain transformation matrices we take as the columns,
the transformations on the basis vectors. Therefore, the first column
would represent the transformation on $[1,0]$ the basis vector in the
x-direction.

\textbf{Rotation Matrix:}

Consider rotating the vector $[1,0]$ by a counter-clockwise angle
$\alpha$. Since {[}1,0{]} has magnitude 1 then the new vector \textbf{u}
can be written in component form as

\[\mathbf{u}=\langle{}|u|\cos(\alpha),|u|\sin(\alpha)\rangle{}=\langle{}\cos(\alpha),\sin(\alpha)\rangle{}\]

and therefore this is the first column of $A_\alpha$. We choose
counter-clockwise angles to be consistent with measuring angles from the
positive x-axis towards the positive y-axis. If we rotate the y-basis
{[}0,1{]} by the same angle we'd get a vector \textbf{v} (which also has
magnitude 1),

\[\displaystyle{}\mathbf{v}=\langle{}-\sin(\alpha),\cos(\alpha)\rangle{}.\]

Note the negative sign in the x-component comes from the
counter-clockwise rotation of {[}0,1{]} into the negative-x, positive-y
quadrant. Therefore we see that the rotation matrix can be written as,

\[A_\alpha=\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\alpha)  &  -\sin(\alpha)\\
\sin(\alpha)  &  \cos(\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}.\]

\textbf{Reflection Matrix:} To formulate the reflection matrix we will
think of it in terms of rotation. We want to reflect the basis vectors
around a vector called the reflector, that makes an angle $\beta$ with
the x-axis. Recall that reflection is angle preserving so whatever angle
the reflector makes with the original vector it must maintain that same
angle with the new vector but in the opposite direction. For example if
an initial vector is $\pi/6$ clockwise from the reflector than the new
vector will be $\pi/6$ counter-clockwise from the reflector. The basis
vector {[}1,0{]} is, by definition of the reflector, at a clockwise
angle of $\beta$ from the reflector. Therefore the new vector must be an
angle of $\beta$ counter-clockwise from the reflector or $2\beta$ from
the positive x-axis. Therefore we can consider reflecting {[}1,0{]} the
same as rotating it by $2\beta$. Therefore the new vector \textbf{u} is

\[\mathbf{u}=\langle{}\cos(2\beta),\sin(2\beta)\rangle{}\]

where once again the magnitude is 1 because the vector {[}1,0{]} has
magnitude 1. Now the vector {[}0,1{]} makes an angle of $\pi/2-\beta$
clockwise from the y-axis with the reflector. Therefore the new vector
\textbf{v} must be an angle of $2(\pi/2-\beta)$ clockwise from the
y-axis. However, we require that we measure angles from the positive
x-axis and thus \textbf{v} makes an angle of

\[\frac{\pi}{2}-2\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\beta\right)=2\beta-\frac{\pi}{2}\]
with the positive x-axis. Therefore we can think of \textbf{v} as a
rotation from the x-axis of $2\beta-\pi/2$. Now recall that

\begin{align*}
\cos\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)&=\sin(x)\\
\sin\left(x-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)&=-\cos(x).
\end{align*}

Therefore we can write,

\[\mathbf{v}=\langle{}\sin(2\beta),-\cos(2\beta)\rangle{}\]

so that the reflection matrix $B_\beta$ can be written as

\[B_\beta=\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(2\beta)  &  \sin(2\beta)\\
\sin(2\beta)  &  -\cos(2\beta)
\end{bmatrix}.\]

\textbf{Projection:} For the projection operator, we want to have an
initial vector get projected onto a vector that makes an angle $\theta$
with the x-axis. Therefore, if we know immediately that the resultant
vector \textbf{u} can be written as,

\[\textbf{u}=|\mathbf{u}|\langle{}\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta)\rangle{}.\]

We also need to recall that the formula for projecting some vector
\textbf{v} onto another vector \textbf{w} is

\[\textrm{proj}_\mathbf{w}\mathbf{v}=\frac{\mathbf{w}\cdot{}\mathbf{v}}{|\mathbf{w}|^2}\mathbf{w}.\]

Now, if we call the basis vector {[}1,0{]}, \textbf{i}, then we have,

\begin{align*}
\textrm{proj}_\mathbf{u}\mathbf{i}&=\frac{\mathbf{i}\cdot\mathbf{u}}{|\mathbf{u}|^2}\mathbf{u}\\
&=\frac{\langle{}1,0\rangle{}\cdot\langle{}|\mathbf{u}\cos(\theta),|\mathbf{u}|\sin(\theta)\rangle{}}{|\mathbf{u}|^2}|\mathbf{u}|\langle{}\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta)\rangle{}\\
&=\langle{}\cos(\theta)^2,\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\rangle{}.
\end{align*}

Similarly, for the other basis vector, {[}0,1{]}, which we call
\textbf{j}, we get,

\begin{align*}
\textrm{proj}_\mathbf{u}\mathbf{j}&=\frac{\mathbf{j}\cdot\mathbf{u}}{|\mathbf{u}|^2}\mathbf{u}\\
&=\frac{\langle{}0,1\rangle{}\cdot\langle{}|\mathbf{u}\cos(\theta),|\mathbf{u}|\sin(\theta)\rangle{}}{|\mathbf{u}|^2}|\mathbf{u}|\langle{}\cos(\theta),\sin(\theta)\rangle{}\\
&=\langle{}\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta),\sin(\theta)^2\rangle{}.
\end{align*}

Therefore, the projection matrix is,

\[C_\theta=\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \sin(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}.\]

Now that we have the transformation matrices, we can answer the
questions.

\textbf{(a)$\textrm{Refl}_\beta\textrm{Refl}_\beta$:}

This is equivalent to

\begin{align*}
B_\beta{}B_\beta&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(2\beta)  &  \sin(2\beta)\\
\sin(2\beta)  &  -\cos(2\beta)
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(2\beta)  &  \sin(2\beta)\\
\sin(2\beta)  &  -\cos(2\beta)
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0\\
0  &  1
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

where we have required the identity $\cos(\theta)^2+\sin(\theta)^2=1$.
Notice, this \textbf{is} indeed an identity matrix.

\textbf{(b)$\textrm{Rot}_\alpha\textrm{Rot}_{-\alpha}$:}

This is equivalent to

\begin{align*}
A_\alpha{}A_{-\alpha}&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(-\alpha)  &  -\sin(-\alpha)\\
\sin(-\alpha)  &  \cos(-\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\alpha)  &  -\sin(\alpha)\\
\sin(\alpha)  &  \cos(\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=
\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0\\
0  &  1
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

where we have taken advantage of the odd and even properties of
$\sin(\theta)$ and $\cos(\theta)$. Notice this \textbf{is} and identity
matrix.

\textbf{(c)$\textrm{Proj}_\theta\textrm{Proj}_\theta$:}

This is equivalent to

\begin{align*}
C_\theta{}C_\theta&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \sin(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \sin(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  & \sin(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

which is \textbf{not} an identity matrix.

\textbf{(d)$\textrm{Proj}_{\theta}\textrm{Proj}_{\pi/2-\theta}$:}

This is equivalent to

\begin{align*}
C_\theta{}C_{\pi/2-\theta}&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \sin(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
\sin(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \cos(\theta)^2
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=2\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)  &  \cos(\theta)^2\\
\sin(\theta)^2  &  \cos(\theta)\sin(\theta)
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

where we have used trig identities to simplify the argument
$\pi/2-\theta$. This is \textbf{not} an identity matrix.

\textbf{(e)$\textrm{Rot}_{\alpha}\textrm{Refl}_{\alpha/2}$:}

This is equivalent to

\begin{align*}
A_\alpha{}B_{\alpha/2}&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\alpha)  &  -\sin(\alpha)\\
\sin(\alpha)  &  \cos(\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\alpha)  &  \sin(\alpha)\\
\sin(\alpha)  &  -\cos(\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(2\alpha)  &  \sin(2\alpha)\\
\sin(2\alpha)  &  -\cos(2\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

which is \textbf{not} an identity matrix. Therefore, we conclude, like
before, that only \textbf{(a)} and \textbf{(b)} are equivalent to an
identity matrix.
